An investor once asked me what are the main reasons a bank decides to buy a new core banking system to transformis new features, lower cost, or greater agilityMy response surprised him - clearly a lot. Banks only buy a core banking system when they have absolutely no alternative. Buying a new core for a transformation is like having a heart transplant. You simply don't do it unless you're going to die otherwise. No one goes down the shops and peruses the latest models of ˜hearts' because they fancy the latest model, or want to run a marathon a couple minutes faster. We need to be honest and acknowledge that some purchases are not driven by benefit, but by necessity. In those cases sales and marketing can't create need, they can only service it and prove their solution superior when it arises. Only when we truly accept the reason behind why people buy things, can we serve that need effectively and generate positive outcomes.Agree?

column7: If you're not reaching out to prospects within 15 minutes of them showing interest, you're lighting revenue on fire.I hear so many GTM teams complain about buyer intent not driving impact.The problem 90%+ of the time?Speed. Or lack of it.You need to be acting on buyer intent ASAP. Ideally within minutes. It can't be days, it can't be weeks, it can't be months. Because SaaS products are being bought on a moment's notice.Why does speed matter? At the beginning of the evaluation period, buyers make their short list of solutions to research. Miss that window and you've missed your shot to be considered.$1,000+ ACV contracts are often signed in under a week. You need to reach buyers during the consideration phase.To reiterate: you need to be reaching out to buyers within 15 minutes of them showing intent if you want to maximize impact from buyer intent data.

I've come to think of Koala a bit as a filtering engine. Sounds weird, right?For our customers who are smaller startups, every touchpoint is exciting.- Is it a VC checking things out?- Is it a competitor looking at positioning?- Is it a design partner starting to show more interest?- Could it be our first customer checking out pricing?You don't want to filter anything.But scaled companies are different.Scaled companies typically have hundreds of thousands of "intent events" per month.Some have tens of millions per month. As we've broken out of our initial customer base and started to serve these great companies, we've found the need to becoming a filtering engine show each member of the Sales team 5-10 real-time alerts that are relevant to them.This boils down to a few things.ICP Fit. Is this company a company that looks like other companies who have bought from us? The simple metric that most people start with is # of employees, but it turns out that there's lots of other enrichment data that tends to be valuable. Things like:- Overall tech stack: does this company tend to build internally vs. buy?- Specific tech they are using- ARR- Capital raised- Site traffic- Location of HQTypically, we can find 25% of traffic that accounts for 75-80% of conversions. This is your 'A' fit “ the stuff that should be going to Sales.Bottom of funnel content. Nagging someone as they first start exploring the tool leaves a bad impression we see best results for Sales teams who are patient. Wait until your buyer is really in the consideration/purchase stage of the journey, starting to consume that content or maybe even kick the tires on the product. Swoop in with a few genuinely helpful pieces of advice or content, and you're very likely to book a meeting!Check out the comments for our guide on how it all works #underthehood!

It was 7 years back, when we were sitting in a meeting room at Lenskart.com office in Okhla Delhi, debating if we should invest in increasing delivery speed beyond 5-7 days. There were mixed thoughts in the room. Few suggested we should benchmark US companies. The team came back with the finding that most global companies are committing 7 days delivery time. Another suggestion was to run a consumer survey to know what % of people want glasses urgently - less than 10% wanted glasses urgently. And as always we ran an A/B test to see increase in revenue, csat.At lenskart, we have had a  fundamental belief from the early days that 'good is not good enough'..i.e. what is good for customers today will not be good tomorrow, as everyone wants to raise their quality of life with time. It is not a question of satisfaction but delight!Long story short, after a lot of analysis and paralysis, none of which clearly suggested investing in faster delivery, we went with our philosophy and took a goal of 3 days delivery...In 2022 we launched 3 days delivery in 8 cities. We kept looking for revenue impact, but we could not find a huge difference. We went against data and decided to take it to the next level, by launching this across 55 cities with a promise of 3 or Free....if you don't get your glasses in 3 days, we will give 50% cash back. While we still could not correlate this to sales growth, we saw that our customer support centre had a huge call increase with queries on 3 or Free... I was finally delighted that customers are talking about this...It is these queues that have always mattered to us more than revenue :)Last year, I already started seeding  the idea of Next-Day delivery in the FY24 Vision Document. The initial reaction of the team was that this is not possible and few rightfully questioned the ROI. Just like last time, we again ran some analysis, but this time the mandate was clear, we need to do it...because remember...good is not good enough :)Finally, we launched Next Day delivery in 4 cities this March 24 (yay)...an incredible work by LensKart Team ...you can order prescription glasses up to 9 pm, and we deliver next day. What looked impossible, especially in a model like ours, where every glass is custom manufactured & shipped from a central factory, became possible and that too profitably without raising cost/ order. And since the last few weeks, I get 100s of messages every day from delighted customers ...a great queue :)In Jan, teams started talking about 10 min delivery. And last week we launched #hustlr on 10 min delivery on Blinkit with support of Albinder Dhindsa & we created a special series for cricket fans to support their team..you must try..these #hustlr are just awesome ˜ & blinkit 10m is ˜² Our quality of lives are improving and I believe Indian companies are defining the new standards of customer delight for the globe #domorebemore#makeinindiap.s most eyewear companies globally still commit 7 day delivery

Incumbents are vulnerable.Lots of folks shy away from markets with strong incumbents and prefer to look for whitespace. Mike Maples, Jr is not one of those people. He loves backing outsiders who spot a new path.The key to taking down an incumbent is to force a choice, not a comparison.People don't want something incrementally better. They don't switch because of a comparison, but because they see something radically different.Think about orthogonal asymmetric attacks ” disorient the incumbents, do the opposite of convention, both in the what (the product) and the how (the business model).Business is always a fight. The fight tilts in favor of the startup when it takes the competitive initiative to rewrite the rules of what customers can expect.”Mike leverages the sword and the shield mental model from Clayton Christensen when working with startups going up against incumbents.Shield: Your go-to-market strategy is so different, the customer context you're targeting is so different, that the incumbent doesn't feel the incentive to attack you. This is the shield that gives you time to perfect the technology.Sword: Your sword is then the skills you build with this time that the incumbent lacks. By the time the incumbent realizes you're a threat, your skills are too asymmetric.”One key aspect in the early days, especially in markets with incumbents, is not to waste time with customers who don't value your advantage. They'll ask you for requirements that don't matter for creating a different future because they're conventional thinkers in the present.Many founders are so desperate to show growth that they will take on any customer. Mike instead advises founders to instead select your customers, don't let them pick you. He'd rather founders go slow to find the desperate customers. Once you've got them, you don't have to throw money at the problem of growth ” you only have to syndicate the truth.Real growth is the accelerated accumulation of attractive customers desperate for your advantage.”Next up: Mike's perspective on building early stage teams. Thanks for reading!

column7:
Here’s what a product vision is not:

A succinct, bold, 1-2 sentence statement that describes the change your company wants to make in the world.

That’s a company vision, not a product vision.

A product vision, on the other hand, is a "detailed enough" description of the actual solution you intend to build, over time, in order to realize the company vision. 

Here are some examples of great company visions: 
- Stripe: Increase the GDP of the internet
- Google: Provide access to the world’s information in one click
- LinkedIn: Create economic opportunity for every member of the global workforce 

Hopefully, it’s clear that none of these provide any meaningful product vision or direction.

For example, Google's product people could have pursued the company vision by building a universally accessible, multimedia encyclopedia. That would have been one product vision (anyone remember Microsoft Encarta?).

Or, they could have envisioned a better search engine and gotten to work on that. 

Product visions can take many formats, from a simple “written story” that describes a customer’s experience with the future product, to a “visiontype” comprised of (often annotated) mock-ups of the key elements of the product.

All good product visions, regardless of the format are:
- inspiring
- customer-centric
- successful at bringing the solution to life, at least in broad strokes. 

Speaking of broad strokes — good product visions are clear without being overly prescriptive. They are directive enough to provide a solid “north star” for the product team(s) to work towards, while challenging those teams to figure out the details over time.

Does your company have a true product vision, or are you under the illusion that your company vision is enough?

column7: Have you heard of a flexible demand model? The concept is to put energy use and demand in the control of the customer. In the latest edition of Climate and Energy, I dive into the components that will lead to its success: educating consumers, offering incentives for participation, having infrastructure like Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) in place to support flexible demand, and utilizing smart appliances in the home. This customer-based shift will proactively help reduce high energy demand on the grid in the future.

column7:
A new research article just came out that reminded me of the spaghetti sauce lesson. Do you know it?

A market researcher trained in psychometrics was hired in the 80s by Campbell Soup. His task was to help identify the “perfect” flavor for Prego brand spaghetti sauce (which was getting beat in the market by Ragu). 

Instead of a single, better-than-Ragu sauce, the researcher identified distinct clusters of customer preferences. His results led to the launch of varied sauces like Chunky, Spicy, and Extra Smooth, which, in turn, led to Prego's sales skyrocketing.

In the new article ( https://buff.ly/3wND6Fv ) published just a few days ago, customer satisfaction researchers identified the drivers of satisfaction in airline travel (the specific drivers they uncovered isn’t really the point of this post, but you really want to know what they were, right? OK:

•	Inflight entertainment
•	Seat comfort
•	Online booking
•	Online support)

The primary interest of the researchers was whether machine learning algorithms beat traditional logistic regression in identifying satisfaction drivers (yes! Random Forest for the win!). 

But It’s the secondary finding that reminded me of the spaghetti sauce lesson:

The satisfaction of one segment of customers was most strongly driven by service quality, while another was most strongly driven by amenities.

In my experience, companies often analyze satisfaction feedback across the customer base as a whole. But that approach often averages out distinct segments in a way that ends up reflecting no one!

If you have open-ended customer feedback and want to identify your customers’ satisfaction drivers, give me a call. I can help. If you don’t collect open-ended customer feedback, give me a call, I can help!  👉 carstendhohnke.com

#CustomerSatisfaction #MachineLearning #MarketSegmentation #DataScience #CustomerExperience #BusinessStrategy
